title: U.S. Regulators Cut Number of Vehicles Deemed to Have Faulty Takata Air Bags
text:
U.S. Regulators Cut Number of Vehicles Deemed to Have Faulty Takata Air Bags NHTSA estimate falls to 19.2 million from more than 30 million, recall is still largest in history ENLARGE 0 COMMENTS 
Federal safety regulators, armed with new data from auto makers, said the number of vehicles likely affected by defective Takata Corp. 7312 -2.76 % air bag inflaters is sharply lower than originally estimated, cutting the figure by about 40% to 19.2 million from more than 30 million. 
The recall remains the largest and most complex automotive recall in history and involves 11 different auto makers. 
An official of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Tuesday said new information shows some of the affected vehicles originally thought to be in the U.S. were sold overseas. And, the initial estimate of vehicles thought to be affected proved inflated because of the way certain cars are equipped. 
Takata, a Japanese auto supplier, had said it installed almost 34 million inflaters that can potentially rupture and cause injury especially when exposed to heat and humidity for a prolonged period. Because four million affected vehicles have defective inflaters on both the passenger and driver sides, it was inaccurate to attach such a high estimate to the number of vehicles needing to be recalled and fixed, the official said on a conference call. 
NHTSA now estimates the number of defective inflaters installed in U.S. vehicles totals 23.4 million. The estimate will continue to fluctuate throughout the recall process, said the official, who asked not to be identified by name. The Takata recall is expected to take a significant amount of time to complete because new inflaters need to be made and consumers often ignore recall notices. Related Reading Takata Rejects Senator’s Call for Compensation Fund (July 10) 
Takata’s recall followed a high-profile General Motors Co. GM -2.72 % recall of faulty ignition switches and heightened concerns about vehicle safety and NHTSA’s ability to regulate auto makers. 
Nearly every major auto maker had installed Takata air bags with the flawed inflaters. Honda Motor Co. HMC -4.00 % has been disproportionately affected because of its long and deep relationship with the supplier. 
Injuries and fatalities attributed to the air bag inflaters have been high profile, attracting the attention of U.S. lawmakers, drivers and regulators. Takata, much like GM, has been called to testify to congressional committees. 
The inflaters have been linked to eight deaths world-wide and more than 100 injuries. 
NHTSA said roughly 4.4 million inflaters have been replaced to date, but some of those have been fixed with interim solutions and may need to be replaced again. 
NHTSA officials are conducting extensive public outreach to inform drivers of the safety issue with the inflaters, and plans to hold an event early this fall to further explain its process for ensuring affected consumers have their vehicles fixed. 
The official said the rate of failure of the air bag inflaters varied significantly depending on the type of vehicle and the market where it was sold. Vehicles sold in Florida, for example, appear to be particularly susceptible to the defect, which typically shows itself between 7.5 and 12 years after a vehicle is first sold. 
Separately, the official said NHTSA has received responses from Volkswagen AG VLKAY -2.93 % and Takata regarding a separate issue regarding the failure of a side-air bag inflater in June on a Tiguan sport-utility vehicle. But he said the agency it had nothing to immediately report from its review. 
The NHTSA official said GM also had identified a side-air-bag defect involving a part similar to the one that failed in the Volkswagen as a part of its quality testing, and had recalled affected GM vehicles in Asia and the Middle East. None of the affected GM vehicles were sold in the U.S., the NHTSA official said.
